cards.syntax: SELECT column1, column2 FROM table_name;
cards.description: Retrieves data from a database
cards.example: SELECT name, email FROM users;
cards.explanation: SELECT is used to query data from one or more tables. You specify which columns you want to retrieve, or use * for all columns.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table_name WHERE condition;
cards.description: Filters records based on a condition
cards.example: SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 18;
cards.explanation: WHERE clause filters records that meet a specific condition. It can use comparison operators like =, >, <, >=, <=, and <>.

cards.syntax: INSERT INTO table_name (col1, col2) VALUES (val1, val2);
cards.description: Adds new records to a table
cards.example: INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ('John', 'john@email.com');
cards.explanation: INSERT INTO adds new rows to a table. Specify the column names and the values to insert.

cards.syntax: UPDATE table_name SET col1 = val1 WHERE condition;
cards.description: Modifies existing records
cards.example: UPDATE users SET email = 'new@email.com' WHERE id = 1;
cards.explanation: UPDATE modifies existing data. Always use WHERE to specify which records to update, otherwise all records will be affected.

cards.syntax: DELETE FROM table_name WHERE condition;
cards.description: Removes records from a table
cards.example: DELETE FROM users WHERE id = 5;
cards.explanation: DELETE removes rows from a table. Always use WHERE to specify which rows to delete, or all rows will be removed.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table1 JOIN table2 ON table1.col = table2.col;
cards.description: Combines rows from two tables
cards.example: SELECT orders.id, customers.name FROM orders JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id;
cards.explanation: JOIN combines rows from two or more tables based on a related column. INNER JOIN returns rows when there's a match in both tables.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table1 LEFT JOIN table2 ON table1.col = table2.col;
cards.description: Returns all rows from left table and matched rows from right
cards.example: SELECT customers.name, orders.id FROM customers LEFT JOIN orders ON customers.id = orders.customer_id;
cards.explanation: LEFT JOIN returns all rows from the left table, and matched rows from the right table. If no match, NULL values are returned for right table columns.

cards.syntax: SELECT col, COUNT(*) FROM table_name GROUP BY col;
cards.description: Groups rows with the same values
cards.example: SELECT category, COUNT(*) FROM products GROUP BY category;
cards.explanation: GROUP BY groups rows that have the same values into summary rows. Often used with aggregate functions like COUNT, SUM, AVG, MAX, MIN.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table_name ORDER BY col [ASC|DESC];
cards.description: Sorts the result set
cards.example: SELECT * FROM products ORDER BY price DESC;
cards.explanation: ORDER BY sorts the result set in ascending (ASC) or descending (DESC) order. Default is ascending.

cards.syntax: SELECT col, COUNT(*) FROM table GROUP BY col HAVING COUNT(*) > value;
cards.description: Filters groups based on aggregate condition
cards.example: SELECT category, COUNT(*) FROM products GROUP BY category HAVING COUNT(*) > 5;
cards.explanation: HAVING filters groups created by GROUP BY. It's used with aggregate functions, unlike WHERE which filters individual rows.

cards.syntax: SELECT DISTINCT col FROM table_name;
cards.description: Returns only unique values
cards.example: SELECT DISTINCT category FROM products;
cards.explanation: DISTINCT removes duplicate values from the result set, returning only unique values.

cards.syntax: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM table_name;
cards.description: Returns the number of rows
cards.example: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM users WHERE active = 1;
cards.explanation: COUNT() returns the number of rows that match a condition. COUNT(*) counts all rows, COUNT(col) counts non-NULL values.

cards.syntax: SELECT SUM(col) FROM table_name;
cards.description: Returns the sum of numeric column
cards.example: SELECT SUM(price) FROM order_items WHERE order_id = 123;
cards.explanation: SUM() returns the total sum of a numeric column. NULL values are ignored.

cards.syntax: SELECT AVG(col) FROM table_name;
cards.description: Returns the average value
cards.example: SELECT AVG(salary) FROM employees WHERE department = 'Engineering';
cards.explanation: AVG() returns the average value of a numeric column. NULL values are ignored in the calculation.

cards.syntax: SELECT MAX(col) FROM table_name;
cards.description: Returns the maximum value
cards.example: SELECT MAX(price) FROM products;
cards.explanation: MAX() returns the largest value in a column. Works with numbers, dates, and text.

cards.syntax: SELECT MIN(col) FROM table_name;
cards.description: Returns the minimum value
cards.example: SELECT MIN(price) FROM products WHERE category = 'Electronics';
cards.explanation: MIN() returns the smallest value in a column. Works with numbers, dates, and text.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table WHERE col LIKE pattern;
cards.description: Searches for a pattern in a column
cards.example: SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE 'John%';
cards.explanation: LIKE is used with wildcards: % matches any number of characters, _ matches exactly one character.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table WHERE col IN (val1, val2, val3);
cards.description: Matches any value in a list
cards.example: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE status IN ('pending', 'processing', 'shipped');
cards.explanation: IN allows you to specify multiple values in a WHERE clause. It's shorthand for multiple OR conditions.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table WHERE col BETWEEN val1 AND val2;
cards.description: Filters within a range
cards.example: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE order_date BETWEEN '2024-01-01' AND '2024-12-31';
cards.explanation: BETWEEN selects values within a given range. The range is inclusive, meaning both endpoints are included.

cards.syntax: SELECT col AS alias FROM table_name;
cards.description: Creates an alias for a column or table
cards.example: SELECT first_name AS name FROM users;
cards.explanation: AS creates a temporary name (alias) for a column or table. Makes output more readable.

cards.syntax: SELECT col FROM table1 UNION SELECT col FROM table2;
cards.description: Combines result sets (removes duplicates)
cards.example: SELECT name FROM customers UNION SELECT name FROM suppliers;
cards.explanation: UNION combines the result sets of two or more SELECT statements. It removes duplicate rows automatically.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 INNER JOIN t2 ON t1.col = t2.col;
cards.description: Returns rows when match exists in both tables
cards.example: SELECT users.name, orders.total FROM users INNER JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id;
cards.explanation: INNER JOIN returns only the rows where there is a match in both tables. If no match, the row is not returned.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 RIGHT JOIN t2 ON t1.col = t2.col;
cards.description: Returns all rows from right table and matched rows from left
cards.example: SELECT orders.id, customers.name FROM orders RIGHT JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id;
cards.explanation: RIGHT JOIN returns all rows from the right table, and matched rows from the left table. Opposite of LEFT JOIN.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 FULL JOIN t2 ON t1.col = t2.col;
cards.description: Returns rows when match exists in either table
cards.example: SELECT customers.name, orders.id FROM customers FULL JOIN orders ON customers.id = orders.customer_id;
cards.explanation: FULL JOIN returns all rows from both tables. If no match, NULL values are returned for the missing side.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table_name LIMIT number;
cards.description: Restricts the number of rows returned
cards.example: SELECT * FROM products ORDER BY price DESC LIMIT 10;
cards.explanation: LIMIT specifies the maximum number of rows to return. Often used with ORDER BY for pagination.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table_name LIMIT n OFFSET m;
cards.description: Skips a number of rows before returning
cards.example: SELECT * FROM products LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20;
cards.explanation: OFFSET skips the first N rows. Used with LIMIT for pagination, like showing page 3 of results.

cards.syntax: CREATE TABLE table_name (col1 datatype, col2 datatype);
cards.description: Creates a new table
cards.example: CREATE TABLE users (id INT PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR(100), email VARCHAR(255));
cards.explanation: CREATE TABLE creates a new table in the database. You define columns with their data types and constraints.

cards.syntax: ALTER TABLE table_name ADD col datatype;
cards.description: Modifies an existing table
cards.example: ALTER TABLE users ADD phone VARCHAR(20);
cards.explanation: ALTER TABLE modifies an existing table structure. You can add, modify, or drop columns and constraints.

cards.syntax: DROP TABLE table_name;
cards.description: Deletes a table
cards.example: DROP TABLE temp_data;
cards.explanation: DROP TABLE removes the entire table structure and all its data. This action cannot be undone.

cards.syntax: TRUNCATE TABLE table_name;
cards.description: Removes all rows from a table
cards.example: TRUNCATE TABLE logs;
cards.explanation: TRUNCATE removes all rows from a table but keeps the table structure. Faster than DELETE for removing all data.

cards.syntax: CREATE TABLE t (id INT PRIMARY KEY);
cards.description: Uniquely identifies each record
cards.example: CREATE TABLE users (id INT PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR(100));
cards.explanation: PRIMARY KEY is a unique identifier for each row. It must contain unique values and cannot be NULL.

cards.syntax: FOREIGN KEY (col) REFERENCES other_table(col);
cards.description: Links to a primary key in another table
cards.example: FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id);
cards.explanation: FOREIGN KEY creates a link between tables. It ensures referential integrity between related tables.

cards.syntax: CREATE TABLE t (col datatype NOT NULL);
cards.description: Requires a value (cannot be empty)
cards.example: CREATE TABLE users (id INT, name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL);
cards.explanation: NOT NULL constraint ensures a column cannot have a NULL value. Every row must have a value for this column.

cards.syntax: CREATE TABLE t (col datatype UNIQUE);
cards.description: Ensures all values are different
cards.example: CREATE TABLE users (id INT, email VARCHAR(255) UNIQUE);
cards.explanation: UNIQUE constraint ensures all values in a column are different. Multiple rows cannot have the same value.

cards.syntax: CREATE TABLE t (col datatype DEFAULT value);
cards.description: Sets a default value for a column
cards.example: CREATE TABLE users (id INT, status VARCHAR(20) DEFAULT 'active');
cards.explanation: DEFAULT provides a default value when no value is specified during INSERT.

cards.syntax: CREATE INDEX idx_name ON table(col);
cards.description: Creates an index for faster queries
cards.example: CREATE INDEX idx_email ON users(email);
cards.explanation: INDEX creates an index on a column to speed up searches. Useful for frequently queried columns.

cards.syntax: CASE WHEN cond THEN result ELSE result END
cards.description: Conditional logic in queries
cards.example: SELECT name, CASE WHEN age < 18 THEN 'Minor' ELSE 'Adult' END AS status FROM users;
cards.explanation: CASE creates conditional logic in SQL queries, similar to if-else statements in programming.

cards.syntax: COALESCE(val1, val2, val3, ...)
cards.description: Returns first non-NULL value
cards.example: SELECT COALESCE(phone, email, 'No contact') FROM users;
cards.explanation: COALESCE returns the first non-NULL value from a list. Useful for providing fallback values.

cards.syntax: NULLIF(val1, val2)
cards.description: Returns NULL if values are equal
cards.example: SELECT NULLIF(dividend, 0) FROM calculations;
cards.explanation: NULLIF returns NULL if two values are equal. Useful for avoiding division by zero errors.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table WHERE col = (SELECT col FROM table2);
cards.description: Query nested inside another query
cards.example: SELECT * FROM products WHERE price > (SELECT AVG(price) FROM products);
cards.explanation: A subquery is a query inside another query. The inner query runs first and its result is used by the outer query.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM t2 WHERE condition);
cards.description: Checks if subquery returns any rows
cards.example: SELECT * FROM customers WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM orders WHERE orders.customer_id = customers.id);
cards.explanation: EXISTS returns true if the subquery returns any rows. Often used for checking related records.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t WHERE col > ANY (SELECT col FROM t2);
cards.description: Compares to any value in subquery
cards.example: SELECT * FROM products WHERE price > ANY (SELECT price FROM products WHERE category = 'Premium');
cards.explanation: ANY returns true if the condition is true for any value in the subquery result. SOME is equivalent.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t WHERE col > ALL (SELECT col FROM t2);
cards.description: Compares to all values in subquery
cards.example: SELECT * FROM products WHERE price > ALL (SELECT price FROM products WHERE category = 'Budget');
cards.explanation: ALL returns true if the condition is true for all values in the subquery result.

cards.syntax: func() OVER (PARTITION BY col ORDER BY col)
cards.description: Performs calculations across related rows
cards.example: SELECT name, salary, AVG(salary) OVER (PARTITION BY department) FROM employees;
cards.explanation: Window functions perform calculations across a set of rows related to the current row, without collapsing the result.

cards.syntax: ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY col)
cards.description: Assigns sequential numbers to rows
cards.example: SELECT name, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS rank FROM players;
cards.explanation: ROW_NUMBER() assigns a unique sequential integer to rows. Often used for pagination and ranking.

cards.syntax: RANK() OVER (ORDER BY col)
cards.description: Ranks rows with gaps for ties
cards.example: SELECT name, RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS rank FROM players;
cards.explanation: RANK() assigns a rank to each row. Equal values get the same rank, with gaps in the sequence for ties.

cards.syntax: DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY col)
cards.description: Ranks rows without gaps for ties
cards.example: SELECT name, DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS rank FROM players;
cards.explanation: DENSE_RANK() is like RANK() but without gaps in the ranking sequence when there are ties.

cards.syntax: WITH cte_name AS (SELECT ...) SELECT * FROM cte_name;
cards.description: Creates a temporary named result set
cards.example: WITH high_value AS (SELECT * FROM orders WHERE total > 1000) SELECT * FROM high_value;
cards.explanation: CTEs (Common Table Expressions) create temporary result sets that can be referenced in the main query. Improves readability.

cards.syntax: BEGIN; statements; COMMIT; or ROLLBACK;
cards.description: Groups operations into atomic units
cards.example: BEGIN; UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance - 100 WHERE id = 1; UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance + 100 WHERE id = 2; COMMIT;
cards.explanation: Transactions group multiple operations. Either all succeed (COMMIT) or all are undone (ROLLBACK).

cards.syntax: CREATE VIEW view_name AS SELECT ...;
cards.description: Creates a virtual table from a query
cards.example: CREATE VIEW active_users AS SELECT * FROM users WHERE status = 'active';
cards.explanation: A VIEW is a virtual table based on a SELECT statement. It simplifies complex queries and provides abstraction.

cards.syntax: CONCAT(str1, str2, ...)
cards.description: Joins strings together
cards.example: SELECT CONCAT(first_name, ' ', last_name) AS full_name FROM users;
cards.explanation: CONCAT joins two or more strings together. Returns NULL if any argument is NULL.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table t1 JOIN table t2 ON t1.col = t2.col;
cards.description: Joins a table to itself
cards.example: SELECT e.name, m.name AS manager FROM employees e LEFT JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.id;
cards.explanation: A SELF JOIN joins a table to itself. Useful for hierarchical data like employees and managers.
